items.title: Ocean driven retreat of the Northeast Greenland Ice Stream following the Last Glacial Maximum
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66671-2 Warm Atlantic Water was a major driver of both initial NEGIS retreat from 21.6 ka BP and the collapse of its ice shelf ~15.2 ka BP. This study demonstrates the key role of ice-ocean interactions in controlling ice-sheet retreat.

items.title: Multilayered regulation of TORC1 signaling by Ait1, Gcn2, and SEAC/GATOR during nitrogen limitation and starvation
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66907-1 Budding yeast use multilayered regulation by Ait1, Gcn2, and the SEAC/GATOR complex to control TORC1 activity. This circuit design ensures that cells can adapt to low-quality nitrogen sources or shut down growth during starvation.

items.title: Immunogenicity and safety of co-purified diphtheria, tetanus and acellular pertussis vaccine in 6-year-old Chinese children
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66890-7 In this phase 4 trial, the authors compare the immunogenicity and safety of co-purified diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis combined vaccine (co-purified DTaP) to diphtheria and tetanus combined vaccine (DT) in 6-year-old Chinese children.

items.title: Controlled microphase separation and strain programming in hydrogel fibers toward biomimetic architectures and properties
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66537-7 Replicating the properties of spider silk in synthetic materials is desirable but challenging. Here, the authors report a wet-spinning method using anti-solvent phase separation for polymer hydrogel fibres with favourable structures and properties.

items.title: Structural basis of sodium ion-dependent carnitine transport by OCTN2
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66867-6 Carnitine uptake by OCTN2 supports fatty acid metabolism. Here, authors report cryo-EM structures of human OCTN2, revealing the mechanism of sodium ion-dependent carnitine transport and providing insight into disease-associated variants.

items.title: mTORC1 signaling in group 2 innate lymphoid cells coordinates neuro-immune crosstalk in allergic lung inflammation
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66683-y Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2) are known to contribute to the pathology of allergic asthma but the molecular mechanism by which they are getting activated are not fully known. Here authors show that the mTORC1 pathway, partly via neuromedin U receptor 1 (NMUR1), plays a pivotal role in ILC2 cell activation, and that inhibition of this signalling alleviates allergic asthma in mice.

items.title: Chain-ordered Pt atoms with delocalized electronic structure for improved hydrogen production
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66476-3 Controlling single atoms into one-dimensional chains offers a platform to study atomic interactions. Here, the authors report that Pt chains host delocalized electrons and a distinct active site, giving metallic character and faster hydrogen evolution than isolated atoms.

items.title: Measuring the magnetic fields in the chromospheres of low-mass stars
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66624-9 Magnetic fields in stellar upper atmospheres are key to understanding stellar activity and its planetary effects. Here, the authors study chromospheric magnetic fields in three M-dwarf stars using spectropolarimetric observations, finding fields reaching hundreds of Gauss with complex height-dependent structures.

items.title: Floquet-induced altermagnetic transition in $A$-type antiferromagnetic bilayers
authors: Baoru Pan, Pan Zhou, Yuzhong Hu, Songmin Liu, Binchang Zhou, Huaping Xiao, Xuejuan Yang, and Lizhong Sun
items.summary: Two-dimensional (2D) altermagnetism has attracted considerable attention due to its low-dimensional character and intrinsic combination of spin splitting with zero net magnetization. In previous work, we developed a general stacking theory (GST) to identify stacking-induced altermagnetism in 2D A-ty… [Phys. Rev. B] Published Fri Nov 28, 2025

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09952-6 Author Correction: Evidence for improved DNA repair in the long-lived bowhead whale

items.title: Audio long read: Faulty mitochondria cause deadly diseases — fixing them is about to get a lot easier
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03797-9 Researchers have struggled to precisely edit mitochondrial DNA, but new techniques are bringing this ability within reach.

items.title: Laser cooling traps more antimatter atoms than ever before
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03877-w Studying trapped antimatter could help to explain why our world is so full of matter.

items.title: Momentum mixing solves the Mott problem
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03104-3 Adding momentum mixing in a controllable way to the exactly solvable Hatsugai–Kohmoto model is shown to recover the physics of the Hubbard model, the starting point for understanding Mott physics. The scheme converges as the inverse square of the number of steps, and, as each step is tractable, minimal computational resources are required.

items.title: Quantum superconducting diode effect with perfect efficiency above liquid-nitrogen temperature
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03098-y A device for rectifying supercurrents at liquid-nitrogen temperature with high efficiency is demonstrated. This is a practical step towards implementing dissipationless electronics.

items.title: Super-expansive thermo-reversible interstitial solid solution of nanocrystal superlattices with mesogens
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02388-3 Combining liquid crystals and nanocrystals functionalized with promesogenic ligands yields an interstitial colloidal solid solution exhibiting high thermal expansivity and reversible superlattice phase transitions driven by mesogen diffusion.

items.title: Self-assembled cell-scale containers made from DNA origami membranes
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02418-0 Through the programmable self-assembly of lipid-inspired radially symmetric DNA, porous molecular membranes and cell-sized compartments are formed with applications in bottom-up biology and soft robotics.
